content.webTitle: England 2-1 China | Women’s international friendly match report

fields.headline: England hold on to beat China thanks to Jodie Taylor and Fran Kirby goals
fields.bodyText: There were perhaps more questions than answers as England won their last match before the head coach Mark Sampson names his 23-player squad for the World Cup finals in Canada during June. It was a less than convincing victory, however, despite beginning with two early goals. Sampson at least gave a hint of his preferred starting line-up, having said in the build-up to Thursday night’s game that he would select “the best team” to face China – or at least the best available as three regulars, the defenders Steph Houghton and Lucy Bronze plus the winger Karen Carney, were missing through injury. Sampson made only two changes from his team’s previous match, the 1-0 victory over Canada in last month’s Cyprus Cup final, Jade Moore replacing Carney and Fran Kirby taking over from Lianne Sanderson up front. Kirby impressed alongside her partner Jodie Taylor, each of them scoring in the first 10 minutes, but after the striker Wang Shanshan’s 17th-minute reply England’s play was often disjointed as they failed to build on a fine opening spell. “It was an important result for us,” said Sampson. “We wanted to maintain momentum after our success in Cyprus and against a very difficult Chinese team we were outstanding in spells, especially in the first 15 minutes when we scored twice and should have scored four.” Sampson used six substitutes during a game that left him still pondering his World Cup squad selection, admitting he was “nowhere near” whittling down a list of what he regards as 35 players with a “realistic chance of selection” in the final 23. “There’s [still] a huge opportunity for players to fight for a place,” he insisted. “There’s also a lot of WSL [Women’s Super League] football to be played between now and the tournament, so players can play their way in – or potentially play their way out. The players need to feel that pressure, to understand how important performance levels are between now and the tournament and make sure they’re in the best possible position to get selected. “We’ve made it clear to them that they really have to push themselves. If you look at the history of England squads or World Cups in general, there’s always potentially someone there – look at Harry Kane – who’s come from nowhere to really stake a claim. If that’s the case it will be a huge bonus to us, and there’s no reason why it shouldn’t happen.” For Kane perhaps read Ellen White, the Notts County striker who was reintroduced to the squad for this game after missing the whole of last season through a cruciate-ligament injury – though she was given only a couple of minutes’ game time as substitute on Thuesday night, when England went searching for a third goal to kill off the game. They had made the brightest of starts, Taylor bundling in the opening goal from a Kirby cross and then Kirby doubling the lead with a neat turn and shot following good link-up play between Taylor and the captain Jordan Nobbs. Jade Moore wasted a simple chance for a third goal when she shot against a post after the goalkeeper Zhang Yue had miskicked an intended clearance straight into the winger’s path. China pulled a goal back when Wang Shanshan took advantage of a hesitant England defence to head in a Wang Shuang corner. Although England went close again as the midfielder Jill Scott’s header was saved by Yue, China were right back in the game and it took a fine diving save by the goalkeeper Siobhan Chamberlain to deny the central defender Li Dongna an equaliser four minutes before half-time. Kirby almost restored the home team’s two-goal advantage with a 58th minute shot that forced Yue into a smart goal-line save, but 10 minutes later Chamberlain had to produce another good stop to keep out a Shuang cross-shot. And in the 76th minute Wang Shanshan should have equalised but completely missed her kick from six yards out. Either side might have won the game in the closing stages, but England were worth a victory that took their unbeaten run to five matches and Sampson’s record, ahead of the World Cup, to 14 wins and only three defeats – to the world’s top three nations – Germany, USA and France – in the 19 games since he took charge 16 months ago. England: Chamberlain; A. Scott, Bassett, Greenwood, Rafferty (Stoney 72); Nobbs (Potter 84), J. Scott (White 90), Williams, Moore (Duggan 62); Taylor (Sanderson 79), Kirby (Aluko 72). Subs not used: Bardsley, Stokes, Bonner, Chapman, Clarke, Telford, Asante, Davison, Dowie. China: Yue; L. Shanshan, Jun, Dongna, Rong; Yanlu (Peng 66), Ruyin, Guixin (Ying 85), Shuang; W. Shanshan, Jiali (Rui 46). Subs not used: Jiayue, Li, Shimeng, Qi, Jiahui, Lisi. Referee: Morag Pirie (Scotland). Attendance: 5,665
